deliberation: Considered whether the prophetic formula 'the word of YHWH came to me' is purely formulaic or still figurative. It treats 'word' as a dynamic agent that moves, which is a conventional personification/metaphor for revelation, so I counted one instance.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
vehicle: a moving, arriving 'word' as if a person or messenger
ground: initiative and active approach from outside the prophet
instances.explanation: The 'word' is portrayed as an agent that 'comes' to the prophet, personifying divine speech and metaphorically describing revelation as a visiting entity.

deliberation: I checked heart-language, the claim to divinity, and spatial phrases. I identified three distinct metaphoric/idiomatic expressions: (1) a 'raised' heart for pride, (2) enthronement 'in the heart of the seas' as a divine seat, and (3) making one's heart like the heart of God.

instances.english_text: you have been so haughty (lit. 'your heart has been raised')
target: the inner attitude of the prince of Tyre
vehicle: a heart that is physically high/raised up
instances.explanation: The Hebrew idiom 'your heart has been raised' uses spatial height as a metaphor for pride, depicting inner arrogance as upward elevation.

instances.hebrew_text: אֵ֣ל אָ֔נִי מוֹשַׁ֧ב אֱלֹהִ֛ים יָשַׁ֖בְתִּי בְּלֵ֣ב יַמִּ֑ים
instances.english_text: “I am a god; I sit enthroned like a god in the heart of the seas”
target: the political position of the ruler of Tyre
vehicle: a divine throne at the center ('heart') of the seas
ground: centrality, security, supreme authority beyond human reach
posture: ironic depiction of self-deifying boast to be overturned by judgment
instances.explanation: The prince claims a 'seat of god' in the 'heart of the seas', a metaphor drawing on ancient cosmic imagery of a god enthroned at the world's center, to express imagined invulnerability and supreme rule.

instances.english_text: you deemed your mind (heart) equal to a god’s (lit. 'you set your heart like the heart of God')
target: the inner self-conception of the prince of Tyre
ground: aspiration to divine-level wisdom, autonomy, and authority
posture: condemnation of hubristic self-elevation to divine parity
instances.explanation: The king’s inner disposition is equated metaphorically with 'the heart of God', expressing presumptuous self-deification in terms of matching the divine inner life.

deliberation: Looked for comparisons and exaggeration. The verse uses comparison to Daniel and an absolute claim about secrets. 'No hidden thing is obscure from you' combines a light/darkness metaphor for knowledge and hyperbolic totality, so I treated it as one complex figurative expression.

instances.english_text: In no hidden matter can anyone compare to you (lit. 'every hidden thing has not been darkened from you')
target: the supposed extent of the king’s wisdom
vehicle: hidden things that are 'dark' or obscured from sight
ground: the difference between clarity and obscurity applied to knowing vs. ignorance; plus the impossibility of any secret escaping him
posture: sarcastic overstatement of his reputed wisdom, preparing for his downfall
instances.explanation: Knowledge is depicted using a darkness/visibility metaphor—no 'hidden' matter remains dark to him—and the totalizing 'every hidden thing' is hyperbolic, overstating his insight to heighten the irony of his coming judgment.

deliberation: Checked terms for wealth and making riches via wisdom for metaphor. Here 'made wealth' and 'made gold and silver in your treasuries' describe literal accumulation of riches by shrewd trade. No clear figurative transfer of meaning beyond normal usage.
Again inspected 'heart' language and wealth. The key idiom is 'your heart was raised in your wealth', the standard Hebrew metaphor of vertical height for pride.

instances.english_text: and you have grown haughty because of your wealth (lit. 'your heart was raised in your wealth')
target: the king’s internal attitude produced by wealth
vehicle: a heart being high or lifted up
ground: elevation above others, sense of superiority sourced in riches
posture: moral critique of pride as a result of prosperity
instances.explanation: The idiom uses the spatial metaphor of upward movement ('raised heart') to depict inner pride arising from accumulated wealth.

deliberation: Verse 6 restates the accusation that he made his heart like the heart of God. This is again a clear metaphorical equation of the king’s inner life with God's, so counted one instance.

instances.english_text: Because you have deemed your mind equal to a god’s (lit. 'you have set your heart like the heart of God')
ground: presumed parity in wisdom, authority, and status with God
posture: legal ground for divine judgment, highlighting hubris
instances.explanation: The king’s heart is said to be 'like the heart of God', a metaphor asserting that he views his inner life and authority as on a divine plane.

deliberation: Looked at swords against 'the beauty of your wisdom' and profaning 'your splendor'. The key figurative element is physical weapons attacking an abstract quality (wisdom's beauty), which metaphorically depicts the shattering of his renowned skill and prestige.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהֵרִ֤יקוּ חַרְבוֹתָם֙ עַל־יְפִ֣י חׇכְמָתֶ֔ךָ וְחִלְּל֖וּ יִפְעָתֶֽךָ
instances.english_text: They shall unsheathe their swords against your prized shrewdness (lit. 'the beauty of your wisdom'), and they shall strike down/profane your splendor
target: the king’s reputation, political skill, and royal magnificence
vehicle: swords slashing at physical beauty and 'splendor'
ground: violent removal and defacement of what made him impressive—his wisdom and glory
posture: vivid threat that his celebrated qualities will be publicly ruined
instances.explanation: His 'wisdom' and 'splendor' are treated like a beautiful body that can be attacked by swords, metaphorically portraying the humiliation and dismantling of his renowned skill and glory. Wisdom/splendor also stand metonymically for the whole royal persona.

deliberation: Considered 'the Pit' and 'heart of the sea'. Both are standard metaphors in Hebrew: the Pit as the realm of death and 'heart of the seas' as the central depths. Counted both as distinct metaphors in this verse.

instances.english_text: They shall bring you down to the Pit
target: the king’s coming death and downfall
vehicle: a deep pit or abyss one is lowered into
ground: movement from height to depth, removal from the realm of the living into a place of confinement and ruin
posture: threat of extreme humiliation and finality
instances.explanation: The 'Pit' is a conventional metaphor for Sheol/the grave; being 'brought down' to it depicts death and ruin as descent into a deep hole.

instances.english_text: in the heart of the sea you shall die
target: the physical and strategic location of Tyre and its king
vehicle: the 'heart' as the middle or innermost part of the seas
ground: centrality, surroundedness by waters, seeming security yet inescapable environment
posture: underscores the irony that even in his central, defended island position, death reaches him
instances.explanation: The sea is given a 'heart'—its inner center; this anatomical metaphor expresses Tyre’s location as in the very middle of the waters.

deliberation: Looked for explicit imagery; the force comes from irony: the boast 'I am a god' versus dying helpless before killers. This is not a metaphor but a rhetorical irony contrasting claim and reality, so I marked one instance under 'other'.

instances.hebrew_text: הֶאָמֹ֤ר תֹּאמַר֙ אֱלֹהִ֣ים אָ֔נִי לִפְנֵ֖י הֹרְגֶ֑ךָ וְאַתָּ֥ה אָדָ֛ם וְלֹא־אֵ֖ל
instances.english_text: Will you still say, “I am a god” before your slayers, when you are a human, not a god
target: the king’s self-deifying claim and actual mortality
vehicle: the scene of a supposed 'god' helpless before executioners
ground: sharp contrast between asserted divinity and demonstrated human vulnerability to death
posture: cutting irony meant to expose folly and deflate arrogance
instances.explanation: The verse uses situational irony: the boast 'I am a god' is placed next to the reality of dying at others’ hands, exposing the claim as absurd.

deliberation: Examined 'death of the uncircumcised' for figurativeness. This is a marked phrase where 'uncircumcised' stands for pagan peoples and their shameful fate, a synecdoche/metonymy rather than a simple literal medical description.

instances.english_text: You shall die the death of the uncircumcised
target: the kind of death the king of Tyre will experience
vehicle: 'the uncircumcised' as designation of Gentile outsiders
ground: association with those outside YHWH’s covenant, shameful and godless death
posture: threat that he will share the fate of despised outsiders, not of an honored ruler
instances.explanation: The term 'uncircumcised' functions metonymically/synecdochically for pagan nations and their dishonorable death; the phrase threatens that he will die like them, not as part of God’s covenant people.

deliberation: Same prophetic formula as v.1. Again, 'the word of YHWH came to me' personifies divine speech as an agent that arrives, so I count one conventional personifying metaphor.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
target: YHWH's revelation initiating the lament over Tyre
vehicle: a 'word' that travels and arrives like a visitor
ground: external initiative and directed approach toward the prophet
posture: marks divine origin of the oracle using conventional imagery
instances.explanation: As in v.1, revelation is depicted as a 'word' that actively comes to the prophet, personifying divine speech.

deliberation: Considered the lament form and the phrase 'seal of perfection'. The dirge framing is literal, but 'you were the seal of perfection, full of wisdom and flawless in beauty' clearly uses 'seal' metaphorically for a standard of completeness.

instances.hebrew_text: אַתָּה֙ חוֹתֵ֣ם תׇּכְנִ֔ית מָלֵ֥א חׇכְמָ֖ה וּכְלִ֥יל יֹֽפִי
instances.english_text: You were the seal of perfection, full of wisdom and flawless in beauty
target: the king of Tyre’s former stature and qualities
vehicle: a 'seal' that completes or caps a pattern; flawless artifact
ground: being the finishing, validating standard of completeness in wisdom and beauty
posture: elevates his former glory to make the fall more dramatic
lamenting praise in order to judge
instances.explanation: Calling him the 'seal of perfection' is a metaphor comparing him to a seal that perfectly imprints or completes a design, exaggerating his wisdom and beauty to the point of ideal completeness.

deliberation: Assessed whether reference to Eden and 'the day you were created' is figurative. The Eden imagery is mythic-metaphorical for an ideal garden-like splendor, and 'the day you were created' likely refers metaphorically to royal installation and crafted regalia, so I noted two related metaphors.

instances.english_text: You were in Eden, the garden of God
target: the luxurious, exalted condition of the king of Tyre
vehicle: Eden, the garden of God, archetype of perfect delight and proximity to God
ground: paradisiacal abundance, beauty, and privileged nearness to the divine
posture: heightens the king’s former exaltation by aligning it with primeval paradise
instances.explanation: The king’s former glory is portrayed through Eden imagery, metaphorically placing him in the divine garden to depict a paradisiacal level of splendor and favor.

instances.english_text: prepared the day you were created
target: the establishment of the king’s person and regalia
vehicle: being 'created' as if crafted from nothing on a specific day
ground: his royal person and finery are presented as a deliberate, crafted work of origin, not mere birth
posture: underscores that his exaltation was a bestowed, crafted status, not intrinsic divinity
instances.explanation: The phrase treats the king and his ornate adornments as if they were created like a crafted object on a particular 'day', a metaphor for his royal installation rather than literal ontological creation.

deliberation: Evaluated whether the cherub and mountain imagery are literal or symbolic of royal elevation. In this context, the king is portrayed under the figure of an anointed, shielding cherub on God’s holy mountain, walking among 'stones of fire'—a mythic-visionary metaphor for his exalted, dangerous proximity to the divine.

instances.hebrew_text: אַ֨תְּ־כְּר֔וּב מִמְשַׁ֖ח הַסּוֹכֵ֑ךְ וּנְתַתִּ֗יךָ בְּהַ֨ר קֹ֤דֶשׁ אֱלֹהִים֙ הָיִ֔יתָ
instances.english_text: I created you as a cherub with outstretched shielding wings; and you resided on God’s holy mountain
target: the king of Tyre in his exalted protective role
vehicle: an anointed cherub who covers/guards on God’s holy mountain
heavenly guardian being in sacred high place
ground: exalted nearness to God, protective function, anointed status, and high position over others
posture: casts his royal status in mythic-cultic terms to stress how high he had been raised before his fall
instances.explanation: The king is portrayed under the image of an 'anointed, covering cherub' dwelling on the divine mountain, a metaphor that uses celestial guardian imagery to express his lofty, sacralized kingship.

instances.english_text: You walked among stones of fire
target: the sphere in which the king operated in his exalted state
vehicle: 'stones of fire'—fiery, glowing stones in a divine realm
ground: a setting of intense glory and danger, proximity to divine fire/light
posture: intensifies the portrayal of his privileged but perilous nearness to the divine sphere
instances.explanation: The image of 'walking among stones of fire' is metaphorical, evoking a realm of blazing, precious intensity to convey the king’s movement within a sphere of extraordinary divine glory and peril.

deliberation: Considered 'iniquity was found in you'; while 'found' is metaphorical for discovery, it is a very common idiom for detecting sin. The verse otherwise straightforwardly contrasts original integrity with later wrongdoing. I judged no distinctive figurative expression warrants separate treatment.

Here the earlier cherub/mountain/stones-of-fire imagery is re-used for the expulsion: 'I profaned you from the mountain of God' and 'destroyed you, O covering cherub, from among the stones of fire'. This continues the mythic metaphor of his exalted status by narrating his removal from that symbolic realm, so counted it as one composite figurative instance.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֲחַלֶּלְךָ֩ מֵהַ֨ר אֱלֹהִ֤ים וָֽאַבֶּדְךָ֙ כְּר֣וּב הַסֹּכֵ֔ךְ מִתּ֖וֹךְ אַבְנֵי־אֵֽשׁ
instances.english_text: So I have struck you down from the mountain of God, and I have destroyed you, O shielding cherub, from among the stones of fire
target: the king’s removal from exalted, sacralized kingship
vehicle: a covering cherub expelled from God’s mountain and from amidst fiery stones
heavenly guardian cast out of sacred realm
ground: forfeiture of privileged proximity to God, loss of high position and glory
posture: portrays his judgment as a cosmic-scale fall from the divine realm itself
instances.explanation: The king, already depicted as a cherub on God’s mountain, is now said to be removed and destroyed from that realm, extending the earlier metaphor to describe his catastrophic loss of status.

deliberation: Looked at pride and humiliation imagery. The verse has (1) the familiar 'your heart was raised in your beauty' metaphor for pride, and (2) 'I cast you to the ground', a descent metaphor for humiliation and overthrow. I treated them as two distinct figurative expressions.

instances.english_text: You grew haughty because of your beauty (lit. 'your heart was raised in your beauty')
target: the king’s inner attitude produced by his physical/royal beauty
vehicle: a heart becoming high or elevated
ground: sense of superiority and elevation over others due to attractiveness
posture: moral explanation of his fall—pride induced by aesthetic splendor
instances.explanation: The idiom uses the metaphor of an elevated heart to picture pride arising from beauty.

instances.english_text: I have cast you to the ground
target: the king’s loss of exalted status and power
vehicle: a body being thrown down from height to the earth
ground: transition from height to lowliness, from exaltation to abasement
posture: vividly portrays his downfall as a forceful humiliation
instances.explanation: Throwing him 'to the ground' metaphorically represents the drastic humiliation and political collapse of someone formerly elevated.

deliberation: Noted two strong images: (1) fire brought out from within him that devours him, and (2) being made into ashes on the earth. Both are vivid metaphors for self-destructive judgment and total ruin.

instances.english_text: So I made a fire issue from you, and it has devoured you
target: the consequences of the king’s own sin and guilt leading to his ruin
vehicle: a consuming fire emerging from within a person
ground: his own iniquity becomes the very means of his destruction, inner corruption eating him up
posture: depicts judgment as self-incurred and total, heightening moral seriousness
instances.explanation: Fire originating from within and devouring him metaphorically portrays his guilt and violence turning inward to destroy him, a hyperbolic image of self-destruction.

instances.english_text: I have reduced you to ashes on the ground
target: the king’s final state after judgment
ground: complete destruction and loss of former form and glory
posture: emphasizes the totality and visibility of his downfall
instances.explanation: Becoming 'ashes on the ground' metaphorically expresses total destruction and humiliation, with nothing substantial remaining of his former greatness.

deliberation: Considered 'you have become a horror' and 'you are no more forever'. The former is a metaphor turning the king into an object of terror; the latter functions as prophetic hyperbole about total, enduring elimination. I counted these as two related but distinct expressions.

instances.english_text: You have become a horror (terror)
target: the king’s reputation and perceived fate among the nations
vehicle: 'horrors/terrors' as a frightening object or event
ground: extreme dread and shock inspired by his downfall
posture: presents him not as admirable but as a cautionary example that provokes fear
instances.explanation: He is said to 'become horrors', turning him metaphorically into a frightening spectacle rather than a glorious king.

instances.english_text: and have ceased to be, forever
target: the continued existence and power of the Tyrian ruler/kingdom
ground: absolute and enduring removal from the historical stage
posture: uses absolutist language to stress the finality of his downfall
instances.explanation: The phrase 'you are no more forever' is hyperbolic idiom for complete and enduring eradication as a power, not a technical metaphysical claim.

deliberation: Repeats the prophetic formula 'the word of YHWH came to me'. As in vv.1,11, I read this as a conventional personification of the word as an arriving agent.

instances.english_text: The word of GOD came to me
target: the new oracle against Sidon given to Ezekiel
vehicle: a 'word' that arrives like a visitor or envoy
ground: external, active origin of the prophet’s message
posture: formula marking divine source and authority of speech
instances.explanation: Again, divine speech is depicted as a 'word' that comes, personifying revelation as an approaching entity.

deliberation: Examined 'set your face toward Sidon'. This is a well-known idiom expressing determined focus or hostility, picturing intent as orienting one’s face. I counted it as a metaphorical idiom.

instances.english_text: set your face toward Sidon
target: Ezekiel’s prophetic orientation and intent toward Sidon
vehicle: turning and fixing one’s face toward a place
ground: determination, deliberate attention and engagement with a target
posture: commands the prophet to adopt a stance of confrontational address toward Sidon
instances.explanation: The idiom pictures determination and focus as physically setting one’s face toward Sidon, a metaphor for resolute prophetic engagement.

deliberation: Considered 'I will be glorified in your midst' and 'I will show myself holy through her'. These express theological concepts of reputation and self-disclosure but do so in relatively direct covenantal language rather than image-transfer. I did not identify a discrete metaphor or other figure beyond normal theological idiom.

Describes pestilence, blood, sword, and the slain in very concrete terms of siege and warfare. While the theology of 'they shall know that I am YHWH' is covenantal, the wording itself is not strongly figurative. No distinct metaphor, simile, or other figure stood out.

Here I checked the imagery of 'prickling brier' and 'painful thorn'. These clearly metaphorize hostile neighboring peoples as injurious plants, so I treat the paired expressions as one extended metaphorical image-cluster.

instances.hebrew_text: סִלּ֤וֹן מַמְאִיר֙ וְק֣וֹץ מַכְאִ֔ב מִכֹּל֙ סְבִ֣יבֹתָ֔ם הַשָּׁאטִ֖ים אוֹתָ֑ם
instances.english_text: no longer be afflicted with prickling briers and lacerating thorns from all the neighbors who despise them
target: the hostile neighboring nations around Israel
ground: constant irritation, wounding, and harassment caused by these neighbors
posture: promises removal of nagging, painful oppression through the image of removing thorns and briers
instances.explanation: Hostile neighbors are figuratively described as 'prickling briers' and 'painful thorns', depicting their oppressive actions as continual pricks and wounds.

deliberation: Describes gathering Israel from the nations and settling them on their own land. This is eschatological, but the language used—gathering, being sanctified in them, settling on the land—is covenant theology stated fairly literally. I found no discrete figurative image beyond standard idiom.

Looked at building houses, planting vineyards, and dwelling securely. These are common covenant blessing motifs; while they can function symbolically for stable life, here they are straightforward promises of restoration, not striking metaphorical transfers. I did not mark any distinct instance.
